name: Interviewer
line: Brilliant so that's it from me i'm now gonna move on to some questions from the audience hi why 140 characters.

name: Dorsey
line: It's a great question so there's two reasons one practical and one conceptual so the practical one first is that we we.

name: Interviewer
line: Originally focused on sms and and the web was really just a way to kind of archive and and see the tweets later on.

name: Dorsey
line: The web was really not a big part of the original vision because we wanted something Noah's there was real time in.

name: Interviewer
line: Life and you could actually feel and and it would buzz your pocket right you could actually physically feel it so the.

name: Dorsey
line: Other thing that was really important to us in working with SMS was making sure that we had a very simple approach and.

name: Interviewer
line: Simple experience and that simplicity met in that case that we would send one message that a message would not break.

name: Dorsey
line: Up and there was a limitation in sms at the time which was a hundred and sixty characters so I had a really really.

name: Interviewer
line: Cheap little nokia device and i loved the thing it was from a virgin and there's a prepaid phone and I wanted to.

name: Dorsey
line: Make sure that it worked on this thing and I had a great experience on it and you know that was a t9 keyboard and a.

name: Interviewer
line: Lot of you probably haven't used the t9 keyboards but I used them and I loved them is super fast and so we we took.

name: Dorsey
line: Those 160 characters and you know i also paid for every text message so we didn't want to we don't want to break it up and.

name: Interviewer
line: And and require you know to receive a text message to get charged twice for one for one tweet this was important to.

name: Dorsey
line: Me but it was also important to if we wanted to go around the world we could actually reach everyone in a in a.

name: Interviewer
line: Cost-effective way as well so the 160 characters we took 20 characters out for the username and we arrived at 140 and.

name: Dorsey
line: That was that but the conceptual side of it was we believed that you know this constraint inspires a creativity and if.

name: Interviewer
line: We really constrain the size of the canvas people might be more off-the-cuff and.

name: Dorsey
line: They might be more in the moment and that's really what we wanted because we wanted this to feel again very live and.

name: Interviewer
line: Just very very human and very of the moment and and the metaphor you know we use is like if I were to give you a red.

name: Dorsey
line: Paintbrush and this huge canvas that that just took up this entire wall and I asked you to go paint that canvas you.

name: Interviewer
line: Compose yourself naturally right because this is a huge canvas and you want to you you want to you want to do the right.

name: Dorsey
line: Thing you know that that's what it kind of goes through your mind but if I were to give you that same paintbrush and.

name: Interviewer
line: That same red paint and i'd give you a business card and I say make a mark just very quick to make the mark and and.

name: Dorsey
line: That's kind of the feeling we wanted was that everything you everything you write everything you tweet is a value to.

name: Interviewer
line: Someone and we wanted to make sure that it feels like you can just fire these things off very very quickly as if you.

name: Dorsey
line: Were you're speaking and and and someone the interpreter is going to devalue it and that's always been really important.

name: Interviewer
line: To us and you know in the in the early days of the service we we got a lot of we got a lot of heat for 140 characters.

name: Dorsey
line: And just how useless twitter was right and and people would would explain in a way that wow this is just a since it's.

name: Interviewer
line: Only only 140 characters you know all people are gonna end up doing is just talk about what they have for breakfast.

line: And we would share that so much like theirs and Twitter is just about what you have for breakfast and you know my.

name: Interviewer
line: Answer to that is well you know sometimes I do tweet about what I have for breakfast and most of the world.

name: Dorsey
line: Could care less and was probably offended because it's so not valuable to them but there was one person in the.

name: Interviewer
line: World that really cares and that's my mom and when she gets the tweet that I just stayed breakfast and one day for.

line: Breakfast and she's really happy because she knows that I'm still eating I'm alive and yeah and I had breakfast and.

line: She loves it so what i mean what's in thing about that is it's all up to who receives a message and who interprets.

name: Dorsey
line: The message and we can't we can't judge the value as it goes out we you know we have to leave it up to the individual to.

line: Really bring value to that message into that tweet and that's always been an important part of our philosophy Thanks.

name: Dorsey
line: What are some of the key lessons from your time at Twitter which helped and influenced the way you set up and.

name: Interviewer
line: Launched swear there were many i you know again I really had no aspiration to be a CEO or to be a leader in the.

name: Dorsey
line: Company or even create a company i just wanted I wanted to to build and use this thing and I was so excited about that.

name: Interviewer
line: And and and really you just learn whatever you have to you learn whatever you have to learn to make that work and.

name: Dorsey
line: And right now a company is just a great vehicle to spread an idea around the world and it allows an idea to to thrive.

name: Interviewer
line: But the idea and the purpose of our work always leads not not the company the company is support and that and the.

name: Dorsey
line: Businesses is oxygen not a to that idea so I think you when when you are tasked with then creating a company you kind of.

name: Interviewer
line: Want to you you you tend to or at least I did you grow up a little bit too fast sometimes and you try to put too much.

name: Dorsey
line: Structure in place or the wrong structure in place and that distracts you from you know really the work that.

name: Interviewer
line: You absolutely need to do and one of the interesting thing I did two big lessons from from that time number one was the.

name: Dorsey
line: Power of instrumentation the power of knowing exactly what's happening within the system and the power of transparency.

name: Interviewer
line: Within the system but also within the company so we would go down a lot in the early days of the company because we.

name: Dorsey
line: Just had no instrumentation at all it's like driving the car flying a plane and not having any sense of how fast.

name: Interviewer
line: You're going right it's extremely dangerous so we we just didn't know what people were doing.

name: Dorsey
line: With it how how the resources were being used and and ultimately it just crashed to a.

name: Interviewer
line: Halt multiple times and little by little we started instrumenting the system and we we built simple things that would.

name: Dorsey
line: Tell us what the system is doing or how people are using it and these seem like of course you build dashboards and of.

name: Interviewer
line: Course you you know you look at the data but you know in the in a moment when you're creating these things that's not.

name: Dorsey
line: What you put first it's it's often an afterthought and the biggest thing that that solved was we stop speculating.

name: Interviewer
line: About what was going on and we could actually point to what was going on and then since we could point to it we could.

name: Dorsey
line: Fix it and we had a ton of communication issues in the company at that time just that we wouldn't talk to each other for.

name: Interviewer
line: In some cases and and in like engineering sometimes we want to talk to operations and when you have those.

name: Dorsey
line: Divisions in the in the company the people using the service actually see the results of it right so any.

name: Interviewer
line: Organizational difficulty actually manifests in the service itself and that's just ultimately rude and selfish.

name: Dorsey
line: And you're putting your own your own mess in front of the people that are using your service or the customer so as.

line: We started instrumenting the system we had a lot healthier communication this is a funny thing because we're building.

name: Dorsey
line: A communication company and we couldn't communicate internally so that was number one and the first bit of code I.

name: Interviewer

name: Dorsey
line: Number two is just how important it is to to really make sure that you're building the right team dynamic and and.

line: We're parting ways with people who who don't and and we had some people in the is a Twitter who were just you know not.

name: Dorsey
line: Down and we can never get it back up and it took me a long time to do it about six months and that's you know a regret.

line: Actually but ultimately when i when i did it and I did it and you know when I when I was when I was when we were.

line: Parting ways i was crying and he was crying and then I went back to tell the company and we're only about seven.

name: Interviewer
line: People and i was crying and the company was crying and like it was at a very emotional period because we were also.

line: Under a lot of stress because we're constantly going down and now we just parted ways with the guy who knew how to.

name: Interviewer
line: Bring the system back up but something really interesting happened immediately after that all these new leaders and the.

line: Really quickly but you don't you don't edit as much and you don't really make sure that there's a great team dynamic.

line: And we give power to the tools and and we can also take that power away from the tools fundamentally I believe.

line: That all tools and all technologies are really just reflections and mirrors of our desires as civilization our desires.

name: Interviewer
line: Is as a humanity and and ultimately i think a reminder and potentially even a crutch that we're already born with.

name: Dorsey
line: Everything that we need and i truly i truly believe that you know and you see this trend where we're moving from these.

name: Interviewer
line: Abstractions where you know before a computer would fill this room and now it fits in my pocket and maybe very soon.

name: Dorsey
line: Around my wrist and just 10 years ago the only way to input something was a keyboard and a mouse and now we're using.

name: Interviewer
line: Our fingers and potentially very very soon we'll be using our voice and and and and more of these these very human.

name: Dorsey
line: Aspects so the interfaces keep becoming more and more human and and and utilizing more of what we're born with.

name: Interviewer
line: And i think what what's important to me about about Twitter is that I think it's a closest thing that we have to right.

name: Dorsey
line: Now that we have to like a global consciousness where you can actually see the world in real-time and not only can.

name: Interviewer
line: You see what's happening from from a news level and from an event level but you can actually see how people think.

name: Dorsey
line: And feel about it and ultimately if we have more of that sort of activity and and the nice thing about Twitter is you.

name: Interviewer
line: Share as much as you want or you can just stop if we have more of that activity though we actually see how.

name: Dorsey
line: People live and what they desire and you know how they want to how they want to see the world how they want to change.

name: Interviewer
line: The world how they want to live in the world and ultimately I believe that that creates a potential for empathy and if.

line: We have more empathy in the world we have more opportunity to remove a lot of a lot of conflict so I think broadly we.

name: Interviewer
line: Can use these tools in a way to build more empathy around the world and that empathy can actually actually.

name: Dorsey
line: Has a chance to to diminish a lot of the conflict that we see in you know where we've also internalized but I I believe.

line: That we have the tools necessary to do it without these technologies as well and I think these technologies really.

name: Dorsey
line: Serve a purpose of reminding us of that and you know maybe in 20 years 50 years we will understand how to lock more of.

name: Interviewer
line: The powers of the mind in order that in order to do that when we're busy exploring space and we're busy exploring.

name: Dorsey
line: The the physical universe but but what really interests me is are the folks that are really exploring that the.

name: Interviewer
line: Depths of the of consciousness and how the consciousness actually interconnects and how it relates and I think.

name: Dorsey
line: Technology provides a model for that that might teach us in different ways so I think it's something to be excited.

name: Interviewer
line: About but it again goes back to these controls of how do I turn it off and how do I turn and turn it on and if that's.

name: Dorsey
line: Not intuitive or if it's not apparent then it's going to feel scary and if we continue to use these words like.

name: Interviewer
line: Technology or disruption or we don't explain that the why of what we're doing with these things these these are things.

name: Dorsey
line: To increase the amount of people who can participate and these are things that increased velocity of communication or.

line: Effort and if you increase velocity and the increase participation you get time back for more meaningful pursuits and I.

name: Dorsey
line: Think that's enough positive but we can also use the tools in a very negative way and we just we have to make that.

name: Interviewer
line: Decision it's ours and ours alone it's not the tools greatest inspiration I that that varies.

name: Dorsey
line: That varies a lot i think i think you always find role models for phases of your life and right now I'm I'm really.

name: Interviewer
line: Obsessed with this artist named robert Irwin I mean how many of you know Robert Irwin okay well he has a he isn't.

name: Dorsey
line: There's a book out about him which is an interview of his life and he's an artist and he he started as a as a painter and.

name: Interviewer
line: Then he started questioning well do i really need the boundaries of the canvas and then he moved to to light and then.

name: Dorsey
line: You know he made these these light sculptures upon walls and he's like well do I really need the the wall and then.

name: Interviewer
line: He started using you know just these massive rooms and he's just constantly questioned every single thing and I love.

name: Dorsey
line: People who who really are comfortable exploring this this this ultimate question of why right so you know why is.

name: Interviewer
line: The question that is just it's the easiest question to ask but it's the hardest question to answer right and.

name: Dorsey
line: That to me is is really you know the driving force and and and what how curiosity manifests is being able to.

name: Dorsey
line: Sometimes a fun little exercises you take a your friend or your parents or or your nephew or nieces or brothers or.

line: Sisters and i would do this to my parents all the time like dad why is the sky blue as I well you know.

name: Dorsey
line: Such-and-such recession like well why like well you know because this and why and he's like that's just how God made.

name: Interviewer
line: It and it's just it's it's interesting how quickly people kind of go to Authority and then there's another route.

name: Dorsey
line: Where instead of going to authorities look well that's that's what we prove to science or you know that that is uh.

name: Interviewer
line: That's how the universe works or that's what you know this person said or that's what you know my boss said or whatever.

line: It is there's another course where we can say I don't know and if you're saying I don't know then that means that.

name: Interviewer
line: You're going to find out and and robert Irwin is someone who just constantly questions every single thing that he.

line: Does in terms of this that's why what like why am i painting in a canvas why is that I don't know and and then he.

name: Dorsey
line: Many throughout my throughout my life Virginia Woolf is another one to whom I love and in terms of just her her prose.

name: Interviewer
line: Relates primarily to the branding of Twitter and you touched briefly on on some branding issues could you talk.

name: Dorsey
line: About a little bit how about how you came up with named Twitter and also the verb to tweet I mean it's something that.

name: Interviewer
line: Everybody knows regardless of whether they're a Twitter fan or user or not and to me it's very iconic and I think you.

name: Dorsey
line: Really nailed it i'd really like to know the thought process about how you got there yeah I I would agree with you I.

name: Interviewer
line: Mean i think um i think twitter is a is one of those brands now that has so much awareness around the world I think it.

name: Dorsey
line: Actually has more awareness or equal awareness to to coca-cola but unlike coca-cola it actually stands for.

name: Interviewer
line: Something it's not just a beverage no offense to coca-cola but I don't drink it.

name: Dorsey
line: But it actually stands for something to people because people bring the meaning to people bring their own purpose to it.

name: Interviewer
line: And people bring their own ideas to it and and they feel ownership over it as well so we uh when we were starting the.

name: Dorsey
line: Company we wanted something that really kind of expressed or had a physical manifestation you know because when you.

name: Interviewer
line: Received one of these messages and they were called updates at the time we didn't have the word tweet when you.

name: Dorsey
line: Received an update your phone would would buzz and we we just thought that was so cool that like you know you do.

name: Interviewer
line: Something virtually and it actually affects something physically that was amazing and it was just so cool for me.

name: Dorsey
line: As a programmer i could write one line of code and I could actually make business pocket buzz which is hard to.

name: Interviewer
line: Say and he's like whoa and takes out his phone and it's a message and I just thought that was so cool so we wanted a.

name: Dorsey
line: Name that really celebrated that and we came up with the word jitter and twitch and both of those words don't really.

name: Interviewer
line: Bring up the best sort of imagery right it's something you actually want to avoid so Noah Noah glass who started OTO.

name: Dorsey
line: And and and and and was formative in the early early Twitter days went to the dictionary and he found the word Twitter.

name: Interviewer
line: And it's actually in the dictionary and it was in the dictionary before the company and it means a short.

name: Dorsey
line: Inconsequential bursts of information and chirps from birds and we saw the definition were like of course I mean.

name: Interviewer
line: This is it this is what we do so we took that name and then like a standard web 2.0 company we removed the vowels and we.

name: Dorsey
line: Started with the name twt tr but we didn't do it just to copy like a Flickr or the you know the the web 2.0 trends.

name: Interviewer
line: We did it because we were text-based and in the United States a short code was was five digits and we wanted.

name: Dorsey
line: We wanted our shortcode to be twt tr so we applied for it and then we found out that this magazine team people had that.

name: Interviewer
line: Shortcode so then we added the vowels back in and we came up with shortcode four zero four zero four which had.

name: Dorsey
line: Nothing to do with what we did but it was available so so then our name was our name was Twitter and because it was.

name: Interviewer
line: Chirps from birds we we we took a bird illustration that we found on the web and that became our logo and and then.

name: Dorsey
line: The people using the service actually came up with the word tweet and you know we a lot of our history is really around.

name: Interviewer
line: People using the service inventing ways of doing things on the surface the at user name the hashtag the retweet I.

name: Dorsey
line: Think one of the one of the new kind of models and and interesting behaviors is this concept of the tweet storm which is.

name: Interviewer
line: You know number one number two number three number four number five number six it's a series of tweets that's meant to.

name: Dorsey
line: Be won all these things have been invented by the people using the service and the word tweet was coined by the.

name: Interviewer
line: People using the service so it's it's really meaningful when you build a brand so that people can bring their own.

name: Dorsey
line: Personality and their their own invention and and product too because that means you haven't just built a.

name: Interviewer
line: Product you've actually built a platform and people can build upon that platform and make their own thing upon that.

name: Dorsey
line: Platform and then if they feel ownership over that they continue to just use it and in really interesting ways so we've.

name: Interviewer
line: Been very very fortunate in in the name and and the bird as our logo and and the current bird just you know when you see.

name: Dorsey
line: It it really stands for something it doesn't just stand for something for the people in the company but stands for.

name: Interviewer
line: Something for the four people in the world and and and and that's something I'm really really proud of but naming is.

line: So difficult and something that i i-i've always had trouble with because my name people always thought my name.

name: Interviewer
line: Was actually john they thought jack was a nickname and no I said you know my name is actually Jack believe me and my.

name: Dorsey
line: Name actually has 14 different definitions and in the dictionary Jack and thirteen of them are derogatory so I.

name: Interviewer
line: Always had i always had issues with my name and a naming in general and but but having the right name just just really.
